item.title: X-Ray Binary Research
item.description: X-Ray Binary Systems An x-ray binary system is a type of binary star system that emits a significant amount of x-ray radiation. It consists of two main components: a compact object, such as a neutron star or a black hole, and a companion star, which is typically a normal star like our Sun or a more evolved star. During my research at Cal Poly Pomona, I studied the x-ray binary system called NGC 300 X-1, which has a highly evolved Wolf-Rayet star and a black hole.
